Mödling is located in the middle of the Vienna Woods (

), at the foot of Mt. Anninger. From 1938 to 1954 it was the 24th district of Vienna, and only since 1954 has it been an autonomous city. Mödling has had a turbulent history; more recently during the Biedermeier period it was a favorite destination for painters, poets, and composers. Ludwig van Beethoven also enjoyed the city and spent some time here.
Mödling does not have its own airport, but
is just 20km away. Unfortunately there is no longer a direct bus connection between the airport and Mödling, making it somewhat complicated to use public transportation. First you'll need to take the
, and from there take a regional train to Mödling. Both trains are timed to coordinate together and leave every 30 minutes. Use ÖBB's
to look up train information online. The trip takes about 50 minutes and costs €7.80.

value: content=No international trains pass through Mödling. Travellers from the south will have to change trains in
; international connections can also be made at main railway station in Vienna (
). Connecting from Vienna's West train station (
) is more complicated, necessitating using Vienna's public transportation system to get to another train station (e.g. via
station) offering service to Mödling. ÖBB's
lists train information online. If you have a lot of luggage or don't want to travel at all by foot, the Mödling city bus (see listing below) leaves from directly in front of the train station.

There are a number of bus routes into Mödling from the region and from Vienna. There are no international bus connections.
The city is easily reachable by car. From the

If you're reasonably fit, Mödling can be seen easily by foot.

value: content=There are three bus routes which cover the city area relatively well; all three routes start in front of the Mödling train station. A map with schedule and bus fares can be downloaded
content=After registration (online or by mobile), pick up a bicycle at any Nextbike location, and drop it off at the same or any other Nextbike spot. A map of pickup and drop-off points can be found
; a brochure with map is available for

If you've come by car, it's better to park and avoid driving during rush hour, but otherwise it's easy to get around the city. There are plenty of paid parking spots in the center, as well as a
on Lerchengasse; a helpful map showing all car parks and garages is available for download
. Outside of the city center there is generally plenty of free parking available.

value: File:Karner hl Pantaleon in Mödling - Detail.jpg
Romanesque carvings on the Charnel House (

content=The foundations of this fortified church date back to the 12th century; following successive attacks by the Magyars and Ottomans the church has been rebuilt a number of times, with the current structure dating to the late Gothic period. The Baroque roof is one of the largest surviving timbre roofs in Austria.

content=This round, late Romanesque ossuary was built in the 12th and 13th centuries, while Baroque bell tower and onion-domed roof were added in the late 17th century. Particularly notable are the fine carvings around the main entrance. The interior of the building was once richly decorated with Romanesque frescoes which during later centuries were completely covered by whitewash and other paintings; through careful restoration work however fragments of several of the original frescoes have been preserved.
directions=entrance through the front door of the former hospital
content=A late Gothic church built in the mid-15th century next to a former hospital (hence the name), noted for its spacious interior vault.

content=Arnold Schönberg lived in this house from 1918-1925, and the building is often referred to as the 'birthplace of 12-tone music' as this is where the composer developed his radically new musical system. The museum has a permanent exhibit with photographs and recordings as well as many of Schönberg's original furnishings and instruments, lending insight to the life and times of the composer.
hours=M T Th 09:00-13:00, Sa 10:00-14:00, Su and holidays 14:00-18:00
price=€3 (adults), €2 (concessions), €1.50 (children), free (NÖ Card); includes admission for the Beethoven House and Volkskundemuseum
content=The museum houses a collection of historic artifacts, from prehistoric until modern times. Along with the permanent exhibit there are special thematic exhibits. A small gift shop is onsite.

content=Beethoven spent the summer months of 1818 and 1819 in the 'Hafner House', which was built in the late 16th century. During his time here he composed the
Sonata for Pianoforte in B-flat major

, this 15th-16th century building houses a collection of objects used in daily life prior to the 20th century.

content=Located on the southern fringe of the Vienna Woods (

), the castle was first built in the 12th century and besieged twice by Ottoman forces; it sustained heavy damage during the Russian occupation following WWII. The castle is owned by the ruling family of
. The castle is open by tour only (in German and English); tours last 40-50 minutes and begin at the top of the hour.

content=The castle was built at the beginning of the 11th century, sustained heavy damage during the first Turkish siege of Vienna in 1529, and was completely burned down following a lightning strike in 1556; since then it has lain in ruins. The castle is a popular hiking destination for locals.
content=Has indoor and outdoor pools, sauna, and an ice rink.
content=This extensive park is part of the Vienna Woods (
(listed above). Popular recreational activities in the park include hiking and mountain biking.
content=An artificial ruined castle from the early 19th century.
content=A 12m-high viewing platform built in the late 19th century which provides excellent views over the area.
Pedestrian zone in the center of town

Most shops are in the central pedestrian area of Elisabethstraße, in the center of town; there are also a few shops along Haupstraße. Most shops are smaller specialty shops and boutiques.

value: directions=5km NE of Mödling, ~10min by car
content=The largest shopping mall in Austria, where you can find just about anything you might need.
content=Serves good and reasonably-priced food, specialises in Viennese cuisine. The small theatre
(tel. +43 2236 24481; office@buehnemayer.at) is located in the basement, and stages concerts, cabarets, and performance art.
content=An excellent restaurant which serves classic Austrian dishes, operating in the Babenbergerhof Hotel (see listing below under 'Sleep').

, is a smaller historic town 20km South of Mödling. Famous for it's bathes and thermal waters. It features many beautiful buildings and beautiful parcs from the Biedermeier period. There is a train and a tram line connecting Mödling and Baden.
